newsitem.title: BRAZIL: BRAZIL DEBT OUTLOOK - Banking on Eurobonds.
newsitem.headline: BRAZIL DEBT OUTLOOK - Banking on Eurobonds.

text.p: Banks, enticed by a recent change in financial regulations, are filling Brazil's new issue pipeline and are expected to remain the nation's most active players in the Eurobond primary market, debt watchers said.

* Banco Real said it will launch a $200 million two-tranche bond this week. The first tranche will be a $125 million three-year bond and the second will be a $75 million four-year bond. WestMerchant is lead managing the deal.
Price talk on the three-year is 175-195 basis points over U.S. Treasuries. The four-year issue was expected to price at a spread of 190-210 bp.
* Banco BMG could also come to market this week with its $100 million eight-year bond, with puts and calls at three and five years. BankBoston is leading the deal.
* Bicbanco was said to be planning a $50 million eight-year bond for the week beginning July 21. ANZ is lead manager. The roadshow for that bond was expected to get under way this week.

Brazilian banks recently benefitted by a Central Bank decision allowing them to park funds borrowed abroad in short-term high-yielding government securities prior to lending to Brazilian clients. The new rule, aimed at helping Brazil's current account financing needs, applies only to banks.

ALSO IN THE PRIMARY MARKET, the Republic of Brazil was seen launching its 10-year 200 million sterling bond soon via Barclays de Zoete Wedd and CS First Boston. Price talk puts the spread at about 250-275 bp over U.K. gilts.

The bond was expected this week or next but may be delayed because of fears of rising U.K. interest rates on a recent budget agreement, traders said. lead manage its $200 million 10-year Eurobond. ABN AMRO also led Eletrobras 10 percent due 2004 ZUQU, which was priced in June 1996 at 338 bp over but has tightened to about 190 bp.
The Eletrobras bond was expected sometime in July.
IN SECONDARY TRADE, spreads on Brazilian paper widened by about five basis points on average, traders said.
"The Treasury market rallied but our prices stayed the same so spreads widened," said a Eurobond trader in Sao Paulo.
"There is also too much paper in the market," he said.
